Award.AwardTitle: INTERDISCIPLINARY UNDERGRADUATE PROGRAM IN NANOTECHNOLOGY AT NJIT: Linking K-12 through Graduate Education via Nanotechnology

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NUE in Engineering program entitled, "INTERDISCIPLINARY UNDERGRADUATE PROGRAM IN NANOTECHNOLOGY AT NJIT: Linking K-12 through Graduate Education via Nanotechnology", under the direction of Dr. Raquel Perez-Castillejos, aims to achieve the following goals: 1) Develop a new 15-week course that will introduce undergraduate students to basic concepts of nano-technology through a series of lectures and hands-on sessions; 2) Develop a nanotechnology-oriented summer research program for undergraduate students at NJIT, which will offer 5 students per year the chance to further pursue their interest in nanotechnology through career development activities, poster and abstract preparation workshops, and presenting their project results at regional or national conferences. 3) Develop a program that will train graduate researchers in educational strategies for effectively teaching and mentoring in nanotechnology. 4) Develop a multi-platform nanotechnology education app-i.e., an app that will be able to run on tablets, computers, and smartphones that will familiarize high school students with nano-scale dimensions.

The four goals of this program aim at taking nanotechnology from the research labs at NJIT into multiple educational settings: from high schools to undergraduate and graduate schools. Implementation of the goals of this proposal will bring together resources and support from all levels of NJIT as well as from local industry in order to provide students with a holistic access to the field of nanotechnology. This proposal has been designed to have the most impact on underrepresented groups...minorities and women. The nanoApp will be distributed among local high schools, especially focusing on Newark, New Jersey, which has large African-American and Hispanic communities. Because NJIT has an undergraduate student population of 33% underrepresented minorities and 25% women it is anticipated that this program will have a remarkable impact on introducing these groups to nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF award allowed the researchers to work in developing a new cross-disciplinary minor in Nanotechnology at NJIT. A significant part of the minor was the development of a new course called NANO488. This course introduces students to nanotechnology through a variety of topics that cover nanotechnology from different points of view including engineering, chemistry, biology, management, ethics, public safety and policy, mathematics, etc. The course is designed in a studio format that complements lectures with hands-on, experimental activities. Graduate students lead the studio preparation in consultation with faculty, polished the lab materials, their delivery, continuity of concepts between lectures (that is linking pedagogical concepts between sessions delivered by multiple speakers/faculty members) as well as the logistics of the studio.The grant allowed many undergraduate students to be trained in research during the summer. The undergraduate students were chiefly women and from other underrepresented groups and minorities. During the summer, the graduate students were in charge of the research training of undergraduate students. Specifically, the graduate students facilitated the lab training, research studies, and other research tasks as and when required. All the undergraduate students have presented their research at major conferences and NJIT poster sessions for undergraduates winning numerous awards. The research by the undergraduate researchers in new areas of nanotechnology during the summer months has elevated the research of the graduate students allowing them to publish significant new research ideas, papers and give talks at various conferences. Further, all the undergraduates trained other high school students from underrepresented groups and other minorities. Most of the high school students using the peer mentorship generated from this interactions have gone on to engineering STEM schools.  Further, this high school students have motivated a significant number of their peer group who have reached out to NJIT researchers and are now researching in various NJIT labs. All the documents regarding course materials and the studios for NANO 488 will be made available to the public.
